name: Mountain Pose
context: The etymology of Tāḍāsana comes from two Sanskrit words: Tāḍa (ताड), meaning 'mountain,' and Āsana (आसन), meaning 'posture' or 'seat.' The term Tāḍa symbolizes the solid, stable, and grounded nature of a mountain, which reflects the strength and steadiness that the pose embodies. Āsana is a common Sanskrit word used in yoga to refer to any posture. Together, Tāḍāsana translates to 'Mountain Pose,' a standing posture that emphasizes physical strength, stability, and alignment, akin to the solid foundation of a mountain. It's alternate name, Samasthitiḥ, refers to 'equal standing' or 'balanced position,' further emphasizing the balance and centeredness that the pose cultivates. Historically, Tāḍāsana did not appear in traditional Hatha Yoga texts but is mentioned in the 1896 Vyayama Dipika, a manual of gymnastics. The pose became a foundational element in modern yoga through the teachings of Krishnamacharya, who incorporated it into the practice of Vinyasa Yoga. His students, Pattabhi Jois and B.K.S. Iyengar, further popularized Tāḍāsana in their respective yoga styles, Ashtanga Vinyasa Yoga and Iyengar Yoga, where it remains a key posture.

name: Downward-Facing Dog
context: The name Adho Mukha Svanasana is derived from Sanskrit, with Adho (अधो) meaning 'downward,' Mukha (मुख) meaning 'face,' and Svana (श्वान) meaning 'dog,' while Asana (आसन) refers to 'pose' or 'posture.' Thus, the name translates to 'Downward-Facing Dog Pose,' evoking the image of a dog stretching its body with its front legs extended and hips raised. This pose mimics the natural stance of a dog stretching after waking, embodying qualities of flexibility, strength, and openness. Historically, Adho Mukha Svanasana has been a core part of yoga practice, appearing in various forms in traditional texts such as the Hatha Yoga Pradipika. It gained further prominence in modern yoga through the teachings of T. Krishnamacharya and his students, including Pattabhi Jois and B.K.S. Iyengar, who incorporated it into their respective yoga styles. Today, it is considered one of the most essential poses in Vinyasa and Hatha Yoga practices, serving as a key foundation for strength, flexibility, and alignment.

name: Plank Pose
context: The name Plank Pose is often referred to as Phalakasana in Sanskrit, with Phalaka (फलक) meaning 'plank' or 'board,' and Asana (आसन) meaning 'pose' or 'posture.' This name directly reflects the shape the body takes while in the pose, which resembles a straight, firm plank or board. The pose is rooted in traditional yoga practices and has been used for centuries to build core strength, stability, and endurance. While it may not appear in the earliest texts like the Hatha Yoga Pradipika, variations of the pose have long been included in strength-building sequences and as part of dynamic physical practices. Plank Pose has gained popularity in modern yoga, particularly in Vinyasa and Power Yoga, where it is often integrated into sun salutations or used as a transition between postures. It became more widely recognized as yoga evolved in the 20th century, especially through the teachings of influential yoga masters like T. Krishnamacharya, Pattabhi Jois, and B.K.S. Iyengar, who emphasized the importance of building strength and stability in the body. Today, Plank Pose is considered a foundational posture in many yoga practices, valued for its ability to engage the entire body and enhance both physical and mental endurance.

name: Upward-Facing Dog
context: The name Urdhva Mukha Svanasana is derived from Sanskrit, with Urdhva (उर्ध्व) meaning 'upward,' Mukha (मुख) meaning 'face,' and Svana (श्वान) meaning 'dog,' while Asana (आसन) refers to 'pose' or 'posture.' Thus, the name translates to 'Upward-Facing Dog Pose,' evoking the image of a dog stretching its chest and lifting its head and body toward the sky. This pose mimics the natural stance of a dog stretching after rest, embodying qualities of strength, openness, and vitality. Historically, Urdhva Mukha Svanasana has been a key component of yoga practice, appearing in classical texts such as the Hatha Yoga Pradipika. It gained significant prominence in modern yoga, especially through the teachings of T. Krishnamacharya and his students, including Pattabhi Jois and B.K.S. Iyengar, who integrated it into their respective styles. Today, Upward-Facing Dog is an essential posture in Vinyasa and Hatha Yoga practices, widely practiced to improve spinal flexibility, chest expansion, and overall body strength.

name: Child's Pose
context: The name Balasana, or Child’s Pose, is derived from the Sanskrit words Bala (बाल) meaning 'child' and Asana (आसन) meaning 'pose' or 'posture.' This pose is often likened to the way a child naturally curls up into a restful, protective position. It embodies qualities of relaxation, surrender, and grounding. Child’s Pose has been an integral part of yoga for centuries, used in various traditional practices as a restorative posture to calm the body and mind. It is commonly employed as a resting pose in sequences, allowing practitioners to re-center and restore energy. Over time, it has become a fundamental pose in many yoga styles, including Vinyasa and Hatha Yoga, providing a moment of respite and deep stretching. Today, Child’s Pose is widely recognized not only for its physical benefits, such as easing tension in the back, hips, and thighs, but also for its ability to promote emotional calm and mental clarity.

name: Warrior I
context: The name Virabhadrasana I is derived from Sanskrit, with Virabhadra (वीरभद्र) referring to a mythical warrior from Hindu mythology, and Asana (आसन) meaning 'pose' or 'posture.' Thus, Virabhadrasana I translates to 'Warrior I Pose,' symbolizing strength, determination, and focus. The pose embodies the stance of a warrior, with one leg lunged forward, the back leg firmly grounded, and arms raised toward the sky, representing readiness and resilience. Historically, Virabhadrasana I has roots in traditional yoga texts, evolving into its modern form through the teachings of prominent yoga figures like T. Krishnamacharya, B.K.S. Iyengar, and Pattabhi Jois, who emphasized its importance in building strength and alignment. Now, this pose is a cornerstone in many yoga styles, including Vinyasa and Hatha Yoga, often serving as a transition in flowing sequences or a standalone pose for grounding and strength-building.

name: Warrior II
context: The name Virabhadrasana II is derived from Sanskrit, with Virabhadra (वीरभद्र) referring to a mythical warrior in Hindu mythology, and Asana (आसन) meaning 'pose' or 'posture.' Therefore, Virabhadrasana II translates to 'Warrior II Pose,' symbolizing strength, focus, and stability. The pose represents the stance of a warrior prepared for battle, with the legs spread wide, the front knee bent, and the arms extended parallel to the floor, embodying power, balance, and determination. Virabhadrasana II has roots in traditional yoga practices but became more widely practiced in the 20th century through the teachings of influential figures like T. Krishnamacharya, B.K.S. Iyengar, and Pattabhi Jois. These teachers helped refine and integrate the pose into modern yoga systems. Today, Warrior II is a foundational pose in many yoga styles, including Vinyasa, Hatha, and Ashtanga Yoga, often used to build strength in the legs, core, and arms while enhancing focus and stability. It is commonly practiced as a part of sequences or as a standalone pose to develop endurance and mental clarity

name: Warrior III
context: The name Virabhadrasana III comes from the Sanskrit words Virabhadra (वीरभद्र), a mythological warrior created by the Hindu god Shiva, and Asana (आसन), meaning 'pose' or 'posture.' Translated, Virabhadrasana III means 'Warrior III Pose,' symbolizing strength, balance, and determination. This pose represents the warrior in a dynamic stance, balancing on one leg while the torso extends forward and the back leg lifts to form a straight line from fingertips to toes. The practitioner’s body forms a T-shape, symbolizing power, focus, and grace. Virabhadrasana III has its roots in ancient yoga traditions but became more widely practiced in the 20th century through the teachings of influential yoga masters such as T. Krishnamacharya, B.K.S. Iyengar, and Pattabhi Jois. These teachers refined and popularized Warrior III in modern yoga systems. Today, Warrior III is a fundamental pose in many yoga styles, including Vinyasa, Hatha, and Ashtanga, known for its ability to improve balance, build strength in the core, legs, and arms, and enhance mental focus and concentration.

name: Extended Side Angle
context: Utthita Parsvakonasana is Extended Side Angle in Sanskrit. 'Utthita' means 'extended,' 'Parsvakona' means 'side angle,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' This pose stretches the legs, hips, and torso while improving balance.

name: Reverse Warrior
context: Viparita Virabhadrasana is Reverse Warrior in Sanskrit. 'Viparita' means 'reverse,' and 'Virabhadrasana' refers to Warrior pose. It stretches the sides of the body and strengthens the legs.

context: Baddha Ardha Chandrasana is Half Moon Bound Pose in Sanskrit. 'Baddha' means 'bound,' 'Ardha' means 'half,' and 'Chandrasana' means 'moon pose.' It is a standing balance that stretches the side body and opens the hips.

name: Hummingbird Pose
context: Mayurasana is Hummingbird Pose in Sanskrit. 'Mayura' means 'peacock,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a balancing pose where the body hovers above the floor, supported by the arms.

name: Peacock Pose
context: Mayurasana is Peacock Pose in Sanskrit. This is the same as Hummingbird Pose and involves balancing the body on the arms while keeping the legs extended behind.

name: Compass Pose
context: Parivrtta Surya Yantrasana is Compass Pose in Sanskrit. 'Parivrtta' means 'revolved,' 'Surya' means 'sun,' and 'Yantrasana' means 'instrument pose.' It is a deep stretch for the hamstrings and shoulders, requiring flexibility and balance.

name: Sleeping Vishnu
context: Anantasana is Sleeping Vishnu Pose in Sanskrit. 'Ananta' means 'endless,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a deep side stretch that involves balancing on one side with the top leg extended and foot flexed.

name: Dragonfly Pose
context: Maksikanagasana is Dragonfly Pose in Sanskrit. 'Maksika' means 'dragonfly,' and 'Nagasana' means 'serpent pose.' It is an arm balance pose that requires core strength and balance.

name: Grasshopper Pose
context: Maksikanagasana Variation is Grasshopper Pose in Sanskrit. This pose is an arm balance where the legs are extended sideways and the body is balanced on the arms.

name: Baby Grasshopper
context: Parsva Bhuja Dandasana is Baby Grasshopper Pose in Sanskrit. 'Parsva' means 'side,' 'Bhuja' means 'arm,' and 'Dandasana' means 'staff pose.' It is a challenging arm balance with one leg extended to the side.

name: Caterpillar Pose
context: Paschimottanasana Variation is Caterpillar Pose in Sanskrit. It is a seated forward fold variation where the body folds forward with the legs extended, promoting a deep stretch for the spine.

name: Revolved Chair Pose
context: Parivrtta Utkatasana is Revolved Chair Pose in Sanskrit. 'Parivrtta' means 'revolved,' and 'Utkatasana' means 'chair pose.' This pose involves twisting the torso while holding the chair pose.

name: Side Stretch Pose
context: Parsvottanasana is Side Stretch Pose in Sanskrit. 'Parsva' means 'side,' and 'Utthana' means 'intense stretch.' It is a standing pose that stretches the side body and hamstrings.

name: Hero Pose with Recline
context: Supta Virasana is Hero Pose with Recline in Sanskrit. 'Supta' means 'reclined,' and 'Virasana' means 'hero pose.' It is a seated pose with the knees bent and the body reclining back.

name: Intense Side Stretch
context: Parsvottanasana is Intense Side Stretch Pose in Sanskrit. It is a variation of Side Stretch Pose that emphasizes the stretch along the sides of the body and the hamstrings.

name: Revolved Crescent Lunge
context: Parivrtta Alanasana is Revolved Crescent Lunge in Sanskrit. 'Parivrtta' means 'revolved,' and 'Alanasana' refers to 'crescent lunge.' This is a twisting lunge that targets the hips and legs.

name: Tortoise Pose
context: Kurmasana is Tortoise Pose in Sanskrit. 'Kurma' means 'tortoise,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a seated forward fold pose that stretches the back and legs.

name: One-Legged Bridge Pose
sanskrit_name: Setu Bandha Sarvangasana with one leg lifted
context: Setu Bandha Sarvangasana with one leg lifted is One-Legged Bridge Pose in Sanskrit. 'Setu' means 'bridge,' 'Bandha' means 'lock,' and 'Sarvangasana' means 'shoulder stand.' It is a variation of Bridge Pose with one leg lifted.

name: Wheel Pose Variation
sanskrit_name: Urdhva Dhanurasana with one leg lifted
context: Urdhva Dhanurasana with one leg lifted is Wheel Pose Variation in Sanskrit. 'Urdhva' means 'upward,' 'Dhanurasana' means 'bow pose.' This variation involves lifting one leg during the backbend.

name: Standing Bow Pose
context: Dandayamana Dhanurasana is Standing Bow Pose in Sanskrit. 'Dandayamana' means 'standing with control,' and 'Dhanurasana' means 'bow pose.' It is a balance pose that combines strength and flexibility.
